title.en: Biographies of Fan Sui and Cai Ze
title.raw: 《范睢蔡澤列傳》 Biographies of Fan Sui and Cai Ze

sentences.zh: 范睢者，魏人也，字叔。

translations.literal: Fan Sui was a native of Wei, courtesy name Shu.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui was a man of Wei, courtesy name Shu.

sentences.zh: 游說諸侯，欲事魏王，家貧無以自資，乃先事魏中大夫須賈。

translations.literal: He traveled among the feudal lords as a persuader, wishing to serve the King of Wei, but being poor with no means to support himself, he first served Xu Jia, the central grand master of Wei.
translations.idiomatic: He traveled among the feudal lords as a persuader, hoping to serve the King of Wei. But being poor and unable to support himself, he first served Xu Jia, the central grand master of Wei.

translations.literal: Fan Sui was a Wei native, styled Shu. He wandered persuading various lords, wishing to serve Wei king, but family poor with no means to support himself, so first served Wei central grand master Xu Jia.

sentences.zh: 須賈為魏昭王使於齊，范睢從。

translations.literal: When Xu Jia served as envoy for King Zhao of Wei to Qi, Fan Sui accompanied him.
translations.idiomatic: When Xu Jia served as envoy from King Zhao of Wei to Qi, Fan Sui accompanied him.

sentences.zh: 留數月，未得報。

translations.literal: They stayed for several months without receiving a reply.
translations.idiomatic: They remained for several months without receiving any response.

sentences.zh: 齊襄王聞睢辯口，乃使人賜睢金十斤及牛酒，睢辭謝不敢受。

translations.literal: King Xiang of Qi heard of Sui's eloquent speech and sent people to grant Sui ten jin of gold and beef and wine. Sui declined with thanks, not daring to accept.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang of Qi heard of Sui's eloquent speech and sent emissaries to present him with ten jin of gold along with beef and wine. Sui declined with thanks, not daring to accept.

sentences.zh: 須賈知之，大怒，以為睢持魏國陰事告齊，故得此饋，令睢受其牛酒，還其金。

translations.literal: Xu Jia learned of this and flew into a rage, believing that Sui had revealed Wei's secret affairs to Qi and thus received these gifts. He commanded Sui to accept the beef and wine but return the gold.
translations.idiomatic: Xu Jia learned of this and flew into a rage, believing that Sui had betrayed Wei's secrets to Qi and thus received these gifts. He ordered Sui to accept the beef and wine but return the gold.

sentences.zh: 既歸，心怒睢，以告魏相。

translations.literal: Upon returning home, he remained furious with Sui and reported the matter to the Wei chancellor.
translations.idiomatic: Upon returning home, he remained furious with Sui and reported the matter to the Wei chancellor.

sentences.zh: 魏相，魏之諸公子，曰魏齊。

translations.literal: The Wei chancellor was one of Wei's royal princes, named Wei Qi.
translations.idiomatic: The Wei chancellor was one of Wei's royal princes, named Wei Qi.

sentences.zh: 魏齊大怒，使舍人笞擊睢，折脅摺齒。

translations.literal: Wei Qi flew into a rage and ordered his retainers to cane Sui, breaking his ribs and knocking out his teeth.
translations.idiomatic: Wei Qi flew into a rage and ordered his retainers to cane Sui, breaking his ribs and knocking out his teeth.

sentences.zh: 睢詳死，即卷以簀，置廁中。

translations.literal: Sui feigned death, was rolled up in a mat, and placed in the latrine.
translations.idiomatic: Sui feigned death, so they rolled him in a mat and placed him in the latrine.

sentences.zh: 賓客飲者醉，更溺睢，故僇辱以懲後，令無妄言者。

translations.literal: The drinking guests got drunk and further urinated on Sui, thus humiliating him to punish others later and ensure no one dared speak rashly.
translations.idiomatic: The drinking guests got drunk and further urinated on Sui, deliberately humiliating him to deter others and ensure no one dared speak rashly again.

sentences.zh: 睢從簀中謂守者曰：「公能出我，我必厚謝公。」

translations.literal: Sui from mat told guard: 'You able release me, I certainly thick thank you.'
translations.idiomatic: From within the mat Sui told the guard: 'If you can release me, I will certainly reward you generously.'

sentences.zh: 守者乃請出棄簀中死人。

translations.literal: The guard then requested permission to throw out the dead man in the mat.
translations.idiomatic: The guard then requested permission to dispose of the dead man wrapped in the mat.

sentences.zh: 魏齊醉，曰：「可矣。」

translations.literal: Wei Qi drunk, said: 'Can.'
translations.idiomatic: Wei Qi, being drunk, said: 'Very well.'

sentences.zh: 范睢得出。

translations.literal: Fan Sui escaped.
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui escaped.

sentences.zh: 後魏齊悔，復召求之。

translations.literal: Later Wei Qi regretted, again summoned sought him.
translations.idiomatic: Later Wei Qi regretted his actions and sent people to summon him again.

sentences.zh: 魏人鄭安平聞之，乃遂操范睢亡，伏匿，更名姓曰張祿。

translations.literal: Wei person Zheng Anping heard it, then led Fan Sui fled, hid, changed name surname called Zhang Lu.
translations.idiomatic: A Wei native named Zheng Anping heard of this and led Fan Sui in flight. They hid themselves and changed his name to Zhang Lu.

translations.literal: Xu Jia as Wei Zhao Wang envoy to Qi, Fan Sui followed. Stayed several months, not getting response. Qi Xiang Wang heard Sui eloquent speech, then sent people grant Sui gold ten jin and beef wine, Sui declined thanked dared not accept. Xu Jia knew it, greatly angered, considered Sui held Wei state secret matters told Qi, thus got this gifts, commanded Sui accept their beef wine, return their gold. After returning home, still angry with Sui, reported to Wei chancellor. Wei chancellor, Wei various crown princes, called Wei Qi. Wei Qi greatly angered, made retainers cane beat Sui, broke ribs knocked out teeth. Sui feigned death, then rolled in mat, placed in latrine. Guests drinking got drunk, moreover urinated on Sui, thus humiliated to punish later, make none dare speak rashly. Sui from mat told guard: 'You able release me, I certainly thick thank you.' Guard then requested throw out dead person in mat. Wei Qi drunk, said: 'Can.' Fan Sui got out. Later Wei Qi regretted, again summoned sought him. Wei person Zheng Anping heard it, then led Fan Sui fled, hid, changed name surname called Zhang Lu.

sentences.zh: 當此時，秦昭王使謁者王稽於魏。

translations.literal: At this time, King Zhao of Qin sent the usher Wang Ji to Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Around this time, King Zhao of Qin dispatched the usher Wang Ji to Wei.

sentences.zh: 鄭安平詐為卒，侍王稽。

translations.literal: Zheng Anping disguised himself as a soldier and served Wang Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Zheng Anping disguised himself as a common soldier to serve Wang Ji.

sentences.zh: 王稽問：「魏有賢人可與俱西游者乎？」

translations.literal: Wang Ji asked: 'Does Wei have any worthy men who could travel west with me?'
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji inquired: 'Are there any worthy men in Wei who might journey west with me?'

sentences.zh: 鄭安平曰：「臣里中有張祿先生，欲見君，言天下事。

translations.literal: Zheng Anping said: 'In my village there is Master Zhang Lu who wishes to see you and discuss affairs of the world.
translations.idiomatic: Zheng Anping replied: 'There lives a Master Zhang Lu in my village who wishes to meet you and speak of matters under heaven.

sentences.zh: 其人有仇，不敢晝見。」

translations.literal: That man has enemies and dares not meet in daylight.'
translations.idiomatic: This man has enemies and cannot risk meeting in broad daylight.'

sentences.zh: 王稽曰：「夜與俱來。」

translations.literal: Wang Ji said: 'Bring him at night.'
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji said: 'Bring him under cover of night.'

sentences.zh: 鄭安平夜與張祿見王稽。

translations.literal: Zheng Anping brought Zhang Lu to see Wang Ji at night.
translations.idiomatic: That night, Zheng Anping brought Zhang Lu to meet Wang Ji.

sentences.zh: 語未究，王稽知范睢賢，謂曰：「先生待我於三亭之南。」

translations.literal: Their conversation was not yet finished when Wang Ji recognized Fan Sui's worth and said: 'Master, wait for me south of the three pavilions.'
translations.idiomatic: Before their conversation had concluded, Wang Ji recognized Fan Sui's talents and said: 'Master, await me south of the three pavilions.'

sentences.zh: 與私約而去。

translations.literal: They made a private agreement and departed.
translations.idiomatic: They reached a secret understanding and left.

translations.literal: At this time, Qin Zhao Wang made ye zhe Wang Ji go to Wei. Zheng Anping falsely as soldier, served Wang Ji. Wang Ji asked: 'Wei has worthy person can with together west wander?' Zheng Anping said: 'Minister village has Zhang Lu master, wishes see lord, speak world affairs. That person has enmity, dares not day see.' Wang Ji said: 'Night with come.' Zheng Anping night with Zhang Lu saw Wang Ji. Conversation not complete, Wang Ji knew Fan Sui worthy, told him: 'Master wait me at three pavilions south.' With private agreement left.

sentences.zh: 王稽辭魏去，過載范睢入秦。

translations.literal: Wang Ji bid farewell to Wei and departed, taking Fan Sui with him to enter Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji took his leave of Wei and set out, bringing Fan Sui along into Qin territory.

sentences.zh: 至湖，望見車騎從西來。

translations.literal: When they reached Hu, they saw carriages and riders approaching from the west.
translations.idiomatic: Upon reaching Hu, they spotted a procession of carriages and horsemen approaching from the west.

sentences.zh: 范睢曰：「彼來者為誰？」

translations.literal: Fan Sui said: 'Who are those approaching?'
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui asked: 'Who comes there?'

sentences.zh: 王稽曰：「秦相穰侯東行縣邑。」

translations.literal: Wang Ji said: 'The Qin chancellor Lord Rang is touring the eastern counties.'
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji explained: 'It is Lord Rang, Qin's chancellor, making his rounds through the eastern counties.'

sentences.zh: 范睢曰：「吾聞穰侯專秦權，惡內諸侯客，此恐辱我，我寧且匿車中。」

translations.literal: Fan Sui said: 'I have heard that Lord Rang monopolizes Qin's power and hates receiving guests from the various lords. This might bring humiliation to me. I would rather hide in the carriage for now.'
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui said: 'I understand Lord Rang holds Qin's power in his grip and detests hosting visitors from other states. This could bring me humiliation. I'd best conceal myself in the carriage for the moment.'

sentences.zh: 有頃，穰侯果至，勞王稽，因立車而語曰：「關東有何變？」

translations.literal: After a while, Lord Rang indeed arrived. He greeted Wang Ji, then stood by the carriage and asked: 'What changes have there been east of the pass?'
translations.idiomatic: Shortly after, Lord Rang arrived as expected. He exchanged greetings with Wang Ji, then stood beside the carriage and inquired: 'What news from east of the pass?'

sentences.zh: 曰：「無有。」

translations.literal: He said: 'None.'
translations.idiomatic: He replied: 'None at all.'

sentences.zh: 又謂王稽曰：「謁君得無與諸侯客子俱來乎？

translations.literal: He again asked Wang Ji: 'Usher, you didn't happen to bring any guests from the various lords with you, did you?
translations.idiomatic: He then asked Wang Ji: 'Usher, did you by chance bring any visitors from other states along with you?

sentences.zh: 無益，徒亂人國耳。」

translations.literal: They are of no benefit; they only disrupt people's states.'
translations.idiomatic: They serve no useful purpose; they merely sow chaos in people's kingdoms.'

sentences.zh: 王稽曰：「不敢。」

translations.literal: Wang Ji said: 'I would not dare.'
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji said: 'I would never dare.'

sentences.zh: 即別去。

translations.literal: Then he took his leave.
translations.idiomatic: With that, he departed.

sentences.zh: 范睢曰：「吾聞穰侯智士也，其見事遲，鄉者疑車中有人，忘索之。」

translations.literal: Fan Sui said: 'I have heard that Lord Rang is a wise man, but he is slow to perceive matters. Just now he suspected there was someone in the carriage but forgot to search it.'
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui said: 'I understand Lord Rang to be a man of wisdom, but his perceptions are slow. Just now he suspected someone was hiding in the carriage yet forgot to have it searched.'

sentences.zh: 於是范睢下車走，曰：「此必悔之。」

translations.literal: Thus Fan Sui got out of the carriage and ran, saying: 'He will certainly regret this.'
translations.idiomatic: At this, Fan Sui leaped from the carriage and ran, exclaiming: 'He will surely come to regret this.'

sentences.zh: 行十餘里，果使騎還索車中，無客，乃已。

translations.literal: After walking more than ten li, sure enough he sent riders back to search the carriage. Finding no guest, they stopped.
translations.idiomatic: After traveling more than ten li, sure enough Lord Rang sent horsemen back to search the carriage. Finding no one inside, they gave up the pursuit.

sentences.zh: 王稽遂與范睢入咸陽。

translations.literal: Wang Ji then entered Xianyang with Fan Sui.
translations.idiomatic: Wang Ji then proceeded to Xianyang with Fan Sui.

translations.literal: Wang Ji bid farewell Wei gone, passing carried Fan Sui enter Qin. Arrived Hu, saw carriages riders from west coming. Fan Sui said: 'Those coming are who?' Wang Ji said: 'Qin chancellor Rang Hou east travel counties cities.' Fan Sui said: 'I heard Rang Hou monopolizes Qin authority, hates receives various lords guests, this fears humiliate me, I rather temporarily hide carriage middle.' After while, Rang Hou indeed arrived, greeted Wang Ji, because standing carriage spoke: 'Guan east has what change?' Said: 'None.' Again told Wang Ji: 'Ye zhe you not with various lords guest sons come together? No benefit, only disrupts people state.' Wang Ji said: 'Dare not.' Then parted went. Fan Sui said: 'I heard Rang Hou wise scholar, his seeing affairs slow, just now suspected carriage middle had person, forgot search it.' Then Fan Sui alighted ran, said: 'This certainly regret it.' Walked ten plus li, indeed made riders return search carriage middle, no guest, then stopped. Wang Ji then with Fan Sui entered Xianyang.

sentences.zh: 已報使，因言曰：「魏有張祿先生，天下辯士也。

translations.literal: Having already reported to the envoy, he then said: 'Wei has Master Zhang Lu, an eloquent scholar of the world.
translations.idiomatic: Having already made his report to the king, Wang Ji then said: 'Wei has a Master Zhang Lu, one of the world's most eloquent scholars.

sentences.zh: 曰『秦王之國危於累卵，得臣則安。

translations.literal: He said: 'The King's state is endangered like piled eggs; with me it will be safe.
translations.idiomatic: He declares: 'Your Majesty's kingdom is in peril like a stack of eggs; with me as minister, it will be secure.

sentences.zh: 然不可以書傳也』。

translations.literal: However, this cannot be transmitted in writing.'
translations.idiomatic: Yet this counsel cannot be committed to writing.'

sentences.zh: 臣故載來。」

translations.literal: I have therefore brought him.'
translations.idiomatic: That is why I have brought him here.'

sentences.zh: 秦王弗信，使舍食草具。

translations.literal: The King of Qin did not believe him and had him lodged where he ate fodder and straw.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Qin remained skeptical and had Fan Sui housed in humble quarters where he ate fodder mixed with straw.

sentences.zh: 待命歲餘。

translations.literal: He waited for orders for more than a year.
translations.idiomatic: He awaited his summons for over a year.

translations.literal: Already reported envoy, because spoke: 'Wei has Zhang Lu master, world eloquent scholar. Said Qin king state endangered like piled eggs, get minister then safe. However cannot book transmit.' Minister thus carried come.' Qin king not believed, made lodge eat fodder straw. Waited orders year plus.

sentences.zh: 當是時，昭王已立三十六年。

translations.literal: At this time, King Zhao had already been established for thirty-six years.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, King Zhao had reigned for thirty-six years.

sentences.zh: 南拔楚之鄢郢，楚懷王幽死於秦。

translations.literal: To the south he captured Ying and Yiling of Chu, King Huai of Chu was imprisoned and died in Qin.
translations.idiomatic: To the south, Qin captured Ying and Yiling from Chu. King Huai of Chu was imprisoned and died in Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦東破齊。

translations.literal: Qin broke Qi in the east.
translations.idiomatic: Qin smashed Qi in the east.

sentences.zh: 湣王嘗稱帝，後去之。

translations.literal: King Min once claimed the imperial title, later abandoned it.
translations.idiomatic: King Min once proclaimed himself emperor, but later renounced the title.

sentences.zh: 數困三晉。

translations.literal: Several times he trapped the three Jin.
translations.idiomatic: He repeatedly placed the three Jin states in dire straits.

sentences.zh: 厭天下辯士，無所信。

translations.literal: He disliked the world's eloquent scholars, trusted none.
translations.idiomatic: He grew weary of the world's eloquent persuaders and trusted none of them.

translations.literal: At this time, Zhao Wang already established thirty six years. South captured Chu Dang Ying, Chu Huai Wang imprisoned died in Qin. Qin east broke Qi. Min Wang once claimed emperor title, later abandoned it. Several times trapped three Jin. Disliked world eloquent scholars, none trusted.

sentences.zh: 穰侯，華陽君，昭王母宣太后之弟也；

translations.literal: Lord Rang, Lord Huayang—these were younger brothers of King Zhao's mother, Queen Xuan.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Rang and Lord Huayang were younger brothers of King Zhao's mother, Queen Xuan.

sentences.zh: 而涇陽君、高陵君皆昭王同母弟也。

translations.literal: Lord Jingyang and Lord Gaoling were all full brothers of King Zhao by the same mother.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Jingyang and Lord Gaoling were King Zhao's full brothers by the same mother.

sentences.zh: 穰侯相，三人者更將，有封邑，以太后故，私家富重於王室。

translations.literal: Lord Rang was chancellor, these three alternated as generals, had fief cities, because of the Queen Mother's influence, their private families were richer and more powerful than the royal house.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Rang served as chancellor while these three took turns as generals and held fief cities. Thanks to the Queen Mother's influence, their private fortunes outweighed the royal treasury.

sentences.zh: 及穰侯為秦將，且欲越韓、魏而伐齊綱壽，欲以廣其陶封。

translations.literal: When Lord Rang became Qin general, he also wished to cross Han and Wei to attack Qi's Gangshou, wishing to expand his fief of Tao.
translations.idiomatic: When Lord Rang became Qin's general, he also sought to bypass Han and Wei to attack Qi's Gangshou, hoping to enlarge his fief of Tao.

sentences.zh: 范睢乃上書曰：

translations.literal: Fan Sui then submitted a memorial:
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui then presented a memorial:

translations.literal: Rang Hou, Hua Yang Jun, Zhao Wang mother Xuan Taihou younger brother; Jing Yang Jun, Gao Ling Jun all Zhao Wang same mother younger brothers. Rang Hou chancellor, three persons alternated generals, had fief cities, because Taihou reason, private families rich heavy over royal house. When Rang Hou as Qin general, moreover wished cross Han, Wei attack Qi Gang Shou, wished broaden his Tao fief. Fan Sui then submitted letter:

sentences.zh: 臣聞明主立政，有功者不得不賞，有能者不得不官，勞大者其祿厚，功多者其爵尊，能治眾者其官大。

translations.literal: I have heard that enlightened rulers establish governance where those with merit must be rewarded, those with ability must be appointed, those with great labor receive thick salaries, those with much merit receive noble ranks, those able to govern the masses receive great offices.
translations.idiomatic: I have heard that enlightened rulers establish governance where merit demands reward, ability demands appointment, great labor brings generous salaries, abundant merit brings exalted rank, and skill in governing multitudes brings high office.

sentences.zh: 故無能者不敢當職焉，有能者亦不得蔽隱。

translations.literal: Thus those without ability dare not undertake positions, those with ability also must not be concealed and hidden.
translations.idiomatic: Thus the incompetent dare not assume positions, while the capable must not be concealed or hidden away.

sentences.zh: 使以臣之言為可，願行而益利其道；

translations.literal: If Your Majesty finds my words acceptable, I wish to implement them and further benefit the way;
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty deems my words acceptable, I wish to put them into practice and further the beneficial way.

sentences.zh: 以臣之言為不可，久留臣無為也。

translations.literal: If Your Majesty finds my words unacceptable, keeping me long serves no purpose.
translations.idiomatic: If Your Majesty finds my words unacceptable, detaining me longer serves no purpose.

sentences.zh: 語曰：「庸主賞所愛而罰所惡；

translations.literal: The saying goes: 'Common lords reward those they love and punish those they hate;
translations.idiomatic: As the proverb states: 'Common rulers reward their favorites and punish their enemies;

sentences.zh: 明主則不然，賞必加於有功，而刑必斷於有罪。」

translations.literal: Enlightened rulers are not like this—rewards must go to those with merit, punishments must be meted out to those with crime.'
translations.idiomatic: Enlightened rulers do not act this way—rewards must be given to those with merit, punishments must be applied to those with crimes.'

sentences.zh: 今臣之胸不足以當椹質，而要不足以待斧鉞，豈敢以疑事嘗試於王哉！

translations.literal: Now my chest is not sufficient to match the executioner's block, my waist not sufficient to await the axe. How dare I test doubtful matters on Your Majesty!
translations.idiomatic: Now my chest is not broad enough for the executioner's block, my waist not sturdy enough to await the axe. How would I dare test doubtful matters on Your Majesty!

sentences.zh: 雖以臣為賤人而輕辱，獨不重任臣者之無反復於王邪？

translations.literal: Though Your Majesty considers me a base person and lightly humiliates me, do you not value that those who entrust ministers to you show no duplicity toward Your Majesty?
translations.idiomatic: Though Your Majesty regards me as a lowly person and casually humiliates me, do you not value that those who recommend ministers to you show unwavering loyalty to Your Majesty?

translations.literal: Minister heard enlightened lord establishes governance, have merit not dare not reward, have ability not dare not appoint, labor great their salary thick, merit many their rank noble, able govern masses their office great. Thus no ability dare not undertake position, have ability also not get concealed hidden. Make with minister words as acceptable, wish implement increase benefit its way; With minister words as unacceptable, long detain minister no use. Saying: 'Common lord rewards loved punishes hated; Enlightened lord then not so, reward certainly add to have merit, punishment certainly break at have crime.' Now minister breast not sufficient match executioner's block, waist not sufficient await axe, how dare with doubtful matter test on king! Though consider minister base person lightly humiliate, alone not heavy entrust minister without reciprocation to king?

sentences.zh: 且臣聞周有砥砨，宋有結綠，梁有縣藜，楚有和樸，此四寶者，土之所生，良工之所失也，而為天下名器。

translations.literal: Moreover, I have heard that Zhou has whetstones, Song has knotted jade, Liang has hanging smartweed, Chu has harmonious catalpa—these four treasures are born of the soil, lost by skilled artisans, yet become famous vessels of the world.
translations.idiomatic: Furthermore, I have heard that Zhou possesses whetstones, Song has knotted jade, Liang has hanging smartweed, Chu has harmonious catalpa—these four treasures are born from the earth, lost by master craftsmen, yet become renowned vessels throughout the world.

sentences.zh: 然則聖王之所棄者，獨不足以厚國家乎？

translations.literal: Then are the things that sage kings have discarded alone insufficient to enrich the state?
translations.idiomatic: Then are the things that sage kings have cast aside alone insufficient to strengthen the state?

translations.literal: Moreover minister heard Zhou has whetstone, Song has knot jade, Liang has hanging smartweed, Chu has harmony catalpa, these four treasures, soil birth, skilled artisan loss, yet become world famous vessels. Then holy king abandoned, alone insufficient thicken state?

sentences.zh: 臣聞善厚家者取之於國，善厚國者取之於諸侯。

translations.literal: I have heard that those who are good at enriching their families take from the state, those who are good at enriching the state take from the feudal lords.
translations.idiomatic: I have heard that those skilled at enriching their families take from the state, those skilled at enriching the state take from the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 天下有明主則諸侯不得擅厚者，何也？

translations.literal: When the world has an enlightened ruler, why do the feudal lords not dare to monopolize enrichment?
translations.idiomatic: When the world has an enlightened ruler, why do the feudal lords not dare monopolize wealth?

sentences.zh: 為其割榮也。

translations.literal: Because they would divide their glory.
translations.idiomatic: Because they would divide up their glory.

sentences.zh: 良醫知病人之死生，而聖主明於成敗之事，利則行之，害則捨之，疑則少嘗之，雖舜禹復生，弗能改已。

translations.literal: A good physician knows a sick person's life or death, a sage ruler is enlightened about matters of success and failure—benefit then implement, harm then abandon, doubt then test a little, though Shun and Yu were reborn, they could not change what is already done.
translations.idiomatic: A skilled physician knows whether a patient will live or die, a sage ruler is clear about matters of success and failure—benefit then act, harm then abandon, doubt then test cautiously, even if Shun and Yu were reborn, they could not change what has already been done.

sentences.zh: 語之至者，臣不敢載之於書，其淺者又不足聽也。

translations.literal: Words that go to extremes, I dare not load onto the book; those that are shallow are again insufficient to listen to.
translations.idiomatic: Words that are too extreme I dare not commit to writing; those that are too shallow are again unworthy of attention.

translations.idiomatic: King Zhao said: 'I indeed wish to take Han, but Han won't listen—what can be done?'

translations.literal: Fan Sui increasingly close, again persuaded used several years, because requested leisure spoke: 'Minister dwell Shandong time, heard Qi have Tian Wen, not heard have king;
translations.idiomatic: Fan Sui increasingly grew close, and had been advising for several years, thus he requested a private audience and said: 'When I dwelt in Shandong, I heard that Qi had Tian Wen but not that it had a king;

sentences.zh: 聞秦之有太后、穰侯、華陽、高陵、涇陽，不聞其有王也。

translations.literal: Heard Qin have Taihou, Rang Hou, Hua Yang, Gao Ling, Jing Yang, not heard have king.
translations.idiomatic: I heard that Qin had the Queen Mother, Lord Rang, Huayang, Gaoling, Jingyang, but not that it had a king.

sentences.zh: 夫擅國之謂王，能利害之謂王，制殺生之威之謂王。

translations.literal: Monopolize state called king, able benefit harm called king, control kill live might called king.
translations.idiomatic: Monopolizing the state is called a king, being able to benefit and harm is called a king, controlling the might of life and death is called a king.

translations.literal: Now Queen Mother monopolize action not regard, Lord Rang out envoy not report, Huayang, Jingyang etc. attack cut no taboo, Gaoling advance retreat not request.
translations.idiomatic: Now the Queen Mother monopolizes actions without regard, Lord Rang goes on missions without reporting, Huayang, Jingyang and others attack and cut without taboo, Gaoling advances and retreats without requesting permission.

sentences.zh: 四貴備而國不危者，未之有也。

translations.literal: Four nobles complete yet state not danger, none have it.
translations.idiomatic: Four nobles complete and the state not in danger—there has never been such a thing.

sentences.zh: 為此四貴者下，乃所謂無王也。

translations.literal: Do this four nobles under, then called no king.
translations.idiomatic: To be beneath these four nobles is what is called having no king.

sentences.zh: 然則權安得不傾，令安得從王出乎？

translations.literal: Then authority how not incline, commands how get from king out?
translations.idiomatic: Then how can authority not incline, how can commands come from the king?

translations.idiomatic: I have heard that those who are good at governing states solidify their might within and weight their authority without.

translations.idiomatic: Li Kui managed Zhao, imprisoned Lord Father at Shaqiu, and he starved to death after a hundred days.
